questions.question: You must isolate PCI workloads while sharing baseline services (logging, directory, DNS) with non-PCI apps. Which design is strongest?
options: Dedicated accounts for PCI and shared services with AWS Organizations SCPs
Two subnets in one VPC with NACLs
VPC peering between PCI and non-PCI subnets
questions.explanation: Separate accounts enforce blast radius and clearer guardrails; SCPs plus shared services (logging, DNS) accounts keep boundaries explicit.

questions.question: A data lake needs encryption at rest, key rotation, and least privilege for analytics jobs. Which KMS strategy aligns best?
options: Use the AWS managed S3 key (SSE-S3)
One customer managed CMK per account with automatic rotation, scoped IAM policies
A single CMK shared across prod and non-prod buckets
questions.explanation: Customer managed CMKs with rotation and scoped IAM provide granular access control and auditable key use for regulated workloads.

questions.question: You need workload identities to access AWS APIs without long-lived keys from an external OIDC provider. Best option?
options: Store access keys in Secrets Manager
IAM roles with OIDC identity provider and role assumption
Create IAM users with MFA only
questions.explanation: Setting an IAM OIDC identity provider and assuming roles removes static keys and uses short-lived credentials tied to external identities.
